tit.e: Hatsuuri (the first sale of the year)

sen.j: 初売り（はつうり）とは、年が変わって最初に小売店が営業を始めることをいう。
sen.e: "Hatsuuri" means that retailers start business in the new year.
"Hatsuuri" means that retailers start business for the first time in the new year.

sen.j: 通常の営業と異なり、その年1年間の運試しの意味合いをかねた、福袋が販売されることが多い。
sen.e: Unlike their normal business, "Hukubukuro"(grab bags) are sold in many stores, by which customers can try their luck for the year.

sen.j: 正月の初売りに出かけて、その年の初めての買い物をすることを買い初め（かいぞめ）などと呼ぶ。
sen.e: Going to a New Year's "Hatsuuri" and doing the first shopping in the year is called "Kaizome" (first shopping).

sen.j: 昔（1980年代頃まで）は、官公庁の業務が開始される(仕事始め)1月4日以降に初売りを行う小売店が多かったが、24時間営業のコンビニエンスストアが増えた現在では、スーパーマーケットや専門店での元日の初売りも珍しくなくなり、元日に休業するほとんどの小売店も1月2日までに初売りを行うようになっている。
sen.e: Before (until 1980s), many retailers did "Hatsuuri" on or after January 4, when public offices start work (Shigoto hajime); however, now, the number of 24-Hour convenience stores has increased and "Hatsuuri" of January 1 by supermarkets and specialty stores are not unusual, and so most retailers, which are closed on January 1, have come to do "Hatsuuri" on January 2.

sen.j: ファッションビルや百貨店などでは、近年初売りの後に冬のバーゲンセールを行うケースも増えており、店側はまさに『正月返上』で準備に追われることとなる。
sen.e: The cases of fashion buildings and department stores that have a winter sale after their "Hatsuuri" have increased in recent years, which makes stores even busier preparing for the sale with "Shogatsu henjo" (giving up their New Year's holiday).
